journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: A new desired articulation angle for directional control of articulated vehicles

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, K. N. Toosi University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: SH Tabatabaei Oreh, Department of Mechanical Engineering, K. N. Toosi University of Technology, Vanak Square, Molla-Sadra, Pardis, Tehran, Iran. Email: hamedtaba@yahoo.com

abstract.p: In articulated vehicles, one of the main driver’s intentions is that the trailer unit closely follows the path of the tractor unit. However, this expectation is not satisfied even at low speeds. Therefore, it is necessary to develop an appropriate method to reduce or even to eliminate the path tracking error. This article proposes a new desired articulation angle for directional control of the articulated vehicles. The proposed reference value tracking ensures that the rear end of the trailer unit closely follows the trajectory of the fifth wheel. Achieving this goal, a tracking error based on the kinematics of the planar motion of the articulated vehicle is defined. Eliminating the tracking error provides a proper determination of the desired articulation angle between the tractor and trailer unit. A controller designed based on the fuzzy logic theory tracks the proposed reference articulation angle by steering the trailer wheels. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method on both low-speed and high-speed maneuvers, simulations of two maneuvers including low-speed 90° turn and high-speed lane change maneuvers are carried out. The simulation results prove the significant effects of the proposed method on enhancing path following performance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: For reason of economy, the role of articulated heavy vehicles in transportation of freight is growing rapidly. However, the operation of these vehicles on minor roads and city streets is a challenging task because of the lack of maneuverability.1 On the other hand, the stability limits of these vehicles are greatly influenced by the increased weight and dimensions. An unstable motion of the articulated heavy vehicle is a critical issue that may lead to fatal accidents.

Overcoming the difficulties mentioned above, several research efforts have been reported on dynamic analysis and active control systems development in articulated vehicles.2–8 The scopes of these researches are the maneuverability improvement or/and stability limits enhancement of the articulated vehicles. However, the main object of this article falls into the maneuverability improvement through the control of the steering angles of the trailer wheels.

The commonly used performance measure that reflects the maneuverability capabilities of the articulated vehicle is the off-tracking. It refers to the phenomenon that the rear end of the trailer unit does not closely follow the path of the tractor unit. It should be kept in mind that the poor path following ability increases the safety concerns for the surrounding vehicle and destruction of road infrastructures.9 Several research efforts have been reported for the improvement of path following in articulated vehicles.

In 1991, Notsu et al.10 developed a control steering system constructed based on the information of the curse angles. The course angle at any arbitrary point on the vehicle is defined as the angle between the velocity vector of this point and the global longitudinal axis. In Notsu et al.’s method, to achieve path following performance, the controller steers the axles of semi-trailer to make the course angle of the vehicle rear end track the course angle of the vehicle front end. However, this concept does not account for high-speed maneuvers. Furthermore, in tight cornering, the trailer is towed with a certain coupler angle even after the tractor is running in a straight line.

A new active steering controller to achieve perfect path following in different circumstances has been designed by Jujnovic et al.11 in 2005. The proposed steering controller made the rear of the trailer track the path of the fifth wheel in a similar way to Notsu’s controller. Moreover, the controller was implemented on a test vehicle. The test results show that the controller was able to improve low-speed performance relative to passive and command steer vehicles.

A ‘virtual driver’ model for trailer steering control that minimizes a combination of the path tracking error and the lateral acceleration of the trailer center of gravity was introduced by Cheng and Cebon12 in 2008. A linear model was used to design the controller and the proposed method was evaluated in a high-speed lane change maneuver in this research. Cheng et al.13 also explained that steering controller can only reduce the lateral acceleration during transient conditions. So, it is necessary to identify the vehicle behavior. Comprehensive discussions on characterization of the steady-state and transient behaviors of the vehicle and the classification of these behaviors can be found in Pacejka14–16 and Mavros et al.17

From the view point of the vehicle control system design, it is almost clear that tracking a reference articulation angle to have the perfect path following is more straightforward compared to all the methods stated above. A few number of research works have been done in this field of study.

In 1998, Fancher et al.18 approximated the desired articulation angle by a first-order transfer function. The coefficients of the function were chosen in a way that the trailer followed the path of the tractor at highway speeds. Clearly, it is impossible to use the proposed reference value in low-speed cornering with a large articulation angle. In 2006, Fletcher et al.19 implemented a control system based on the partial feedback linearization method using a reference articulation angle to achieve fifth wheel path tracking. The reference articulation angle is defined using the sensed yaw rate of the tractor unit and the lateral velocity at the fifth wheel. However, they neither explained an algorithm of the reference articulation angle determination nor introduced a math formula for this reference value. In 2008, Wang et al.20 derived a desired value for the articulation angle in the case of a constant driver steering angle. In 2010, Chen and Shie21 also used this reference value to design their reference model adaptive controller for jackknife prevention of the articulated vehicle.

Based on the foregoing studies, there is a vital need for devising a systematic method to define the reference articulation angle which covers various paths and different speeds. Therefore, this article presents a novel approach in order to determine the desired articulation angle so that tracking of the reference value will have the outcome of perfect tracking of the fifth wheel path at all speeds.

The rest of this article is organized as follows: a nonlinear planar model of the articulated heavy vehicles is developed in section ‘The vehicle and tyre model’. In the section ‘Derivation of the desired articulation angle’, an innovative approach to derive the desired articulation angle is presented. Then, a fuzzy logic controller is designed to adjust the articulation angle through the manipulating the steering angle of the trailer wheels in ‘Control system design’ section. Finally, in the ‘Results and discussion’ section, the advantage of the proposed approach to enhance path tracking of the fifth wheel is investigated using the computer simulations.

sec.title: The vehicle and tyre model
sec.p: The linear vehicle models provide accurate results for handling maneuvers at low lateral acceleration.22 However, beyond these low lateral accelerations, the vehicle's nonlinearities become significant and nonlinear multi-body dynamics model need to be utilized to investigate the vehicle behavior.23–25 In this article, the main object is the maneuverability improvement at low to mid rang of lateral acceleration. Therefore, a nonlinear planar model of the articulated heavy vehicle has been developed. This model ignores bounce, roll, and pitch motions and has no suspension. However, nonlinear tyre characteristics and loads transfers induced by the lateral and longitudinal accelerations are taken into account in the mathematical model.

sec.title: The vehicle model
sec.p:
The fourteen degrees of freedom model reflecting the directional characteristics of the articulated vehicle is used to test the proposed approach. The articulated vehicle was modelled using two rigid bodies including the tractor with front steerable axle supplying by the driver and the semi-trailer with three independently steerable axles manipulating by the controller. The degrees of freedom are longitudinal, lateral and yawing motion of tractor, the articulation angle between the tractor and the semi-trailer and the rotational motion of each wheel. As shown in Figure 1, the tractor front axle and the three semi-trailer axles are steerable. Figure 1.
Fourteen degrees of freedom articulated vehicle model: (a) top view of vehicle model, (b) wheel model.

Three coordinate systems for the model are considered. The first is the inertial coordinate system (XnYn) fixed to the ground, the second is tractor coordinate system (XtYt) fixed to the tractor’s center of gravity and the third is semi-trailer coordinate system (XsYs) mounted to the semi-trailer CG. The XtYt and XsYs coordinates moving with the tractor and the semi-trailer units have yaw velocities of rt and rs, respectively. So the rate of the articulation can be represented by (1)γ·=rs-rt

The traction and side tyre forces can be expressed in tractor and trailer coordinate systems as follows (2)Fxi=Fticosδi-Fsisinδi (3)Fyi=Ftisinδi+Fsicosδiwith i=1:10 where Fxi and Fyi with (i=1:4) are the respective tractor tyre forces in the Xt and Yt directions; with (i=5:10) are the respective semi-trailer tyre forces in the Xs and Ys directions. The steer angle of ith wheel (δi) is assumed to have the following relationships (4)δ1,2=δft,δ3,4=0,δ5,6=δfs,δ7,8=δms,δ9,10=δrs

The term δft is the steering angle applied by the driver, while δfs, δms and δrs are the steering angles demanded by the controller. In addition, the total longitudinal force, lateral force and yaw moment acting on the tractor unit in tractor coordinate system (XtYt) are given (5)Fxtt=∑i=14Fxi (6)Fytt=∑i=14Fyi (7)Mzt=(Fx2+Fx4-Fx1-Fx3)TWt2 +(Fy1+Fy2)Lft-(Fy3+Fy4)Lrt

Similarly, the total longitudinal force, lateral force and yaw moment acting on the semi-trailer unit are also defined in tractor coordinate system (XtYt) (8)Fxts=(∑i=510Fxi)cosγ-(∑i=510Fyi)sinγ (9)Fyts=(∑i=510Fxi)sinγ+(∑i=510Fyi)cosγ (10)Mzs=(Fx6+Fx8+Fx10-Fx5-Fx7-Fx9)TWs2 -(Fy5+Fy6)(Lrs-Lts)-(Fy7+Fy8)Lrs -(Fy9+Fy10)(Lrs+Lts)

Consequently, the motion equations can be expressed in compact forms by using the total forces and moments defined by equations (5) to (10). The governing equations of the longitudinal, lateral and yaw motions of the tractor unit in XtYt coordinate system can be expressed as (11)mt(V·xt-rtVyt)=Fxtt-Ffx (12)mt(V·yt+rtVxt)=Fytt-Ffy (13)Iztr·t=Mzt+FfyLwt where Vxt and Vyt are the longitudinal and lateral velocities of the tractor CG, respectively; Ffx and Ffy are the coupling forces in the Xt and Yt directions, respectively. In order to simplify the elimination of the coupling forces from the motion equations, the semi-trailer dynamics are derived with respect to the tractor coordinate system (XtYt). Thus, the acceleration of the semi-trailer CG can be expressed as (14)axts=V·xt-rtVyt+Lwtrt2+Lfsr·ssinγ+Lfsrs2cosγ (15)ayts=V·yt+rtVxt-Lwtr·t-Lfsr·scosγ+Lfsrs2sinγ where axts and ayts are the longitudinal and lateral accelerations of the semi-trailer CG in the Xt and Yt directions, respectively. Hence, the equations representing the motion of semi-trailer in XtYt coordinate are given as (16)ms(Lwtrt2+Lfsrs2cosγ+Lfsr·ssinγ+V·xt-rtVyt) =Fxts+Ffx (17)ms(Lfsrs2sinγ-Lwtr·t-Lfsr·scosγ+V·yt+rtVxt) =Fyts+Ffy (18)Izsr·s=Mzs-FfxsinγLfs+FfycosγLfs

Eliminating the coupling forces from equations (11) to (13) and (16) to (18) leads to the following equations represents the planar motion of the articulated vehicle (19)(mt+ms)(V·xt-rtVyt)+ms(Lwtrt2+Lfsrs2cosγ +Lfsr·ssinγ)=Fxtt+Fxts (20)(mt+ms)(V·yt+rtVxt) +ms(Lfsrs2sinγ-Lwtr·t-Lfsr·scosγ)=Fytt+Fyts (21)Iztr·t+mt(V·yt+rtVxt)LWt=Mzt+FyttLwt (22)Izsr·s-mt(V·xt-rtVyt)Lfssinγ+mt(V·yt+rtVxt)Lfscosγ =Mzs-FxttsinγLfs+FyttcosγLfs

sec.title: The tyre model
sec.p: The traction and side forces acting on the articulated vehicle are generated at the contact path between tyre and road. The traction forces are generated for acceleration or braking and the side forces are necessary to adjust the direction of the vehicle. In this article, the Dugoff model is used to simulate the tyre forces.26 The model has some limitations at high lateral accelerations maneuvers. However, in this article, the simulations will be conducted at low to mid rang of lateral acceleration. The inputs of the model are the side slip angle, wheel slip ratio and normal tyre load.
The longitudinal and lateral velocities at each wheel center of tractor unit can be expressed as (23)u1,3=Vxt-rtTwt2,u2,4=Vxt+rtTwt2, v1,2=Vyt+rtLft,v3,4=Vyt-rtLrt

The velocity of the semi-trailer CG in XsYs coordinate must be known to compute the corresponding wheel velocities (24)Vxs=Vxtcosγ+Vytsinγ-Lwtrtsinγ (25)Vys=-Vxtsinγ+Vytcosγ-Lwtrtcosγ-Lfsrs where Vxs and Vys are the longitudinal and lateral velocities of the semi-trailer CG in the Xs and Ys directions, respectively. Thus, the longitudinal and lateral velocities at each wheel center of semi-trailer unit can be computed as (26)u5,7,9=Vxs-rsTws2,u6,8,10=Vxs+rsTws2,v5,6=Vys-rs(Lrs-Lts),v7,8=Vys-rsLrs,v9,10=Vys-rs(Lrs+Lts)
The tyre side slip angle for each wheel can be calculated as (27)αi=δi-tan-1(viui)
The wheel center velocity in the direction of the wheel heading may be computed as (28)uwi=uicosδi+visinδi

So, the longitudinal slip ratio of each wheel is defined as (29)si=uwi-Rωimax(ui,Rωi)with i=1:10 where ωi is the wheel rotational speed. Furthermore, the normal loads of tyres are obtained. In order to closely approximate the actual tyre normal loads, dynamic load transfer effects are also considered. The detailed derivation of the normal forces can be found in Appendix 2. Finally, the traction and the side forces are computed by the Dugoff model as follows (30)λ=μFzi(1-ɛruisi2+tan2αi)(1-si)2Ci2si2+Cα2tan2αi (31)f(λ)={λ(2-λ)ifλ<11 ifλ>1 (32)Fsi=Cαtanαi1-sif(λ) (33)Fti=Cssi1-sif(λ)

sec.title: Derivation of the desired articulation angle
sec.p:
In this section, a desired articulation angle is obtained. The tracking of the proposed desired value ensures that the rear end of the trailer unit closely follows the trajectory of the fifth wheel. Figure 2 schematically shows the planar motion of the vehicle. At the present time (t), the longitudinal and lateral positions of the fifth wheel (point f ) are xf(t) and yf(t), respectively; the longitudinal and lateral positions of the trailer rear end (point S) are xs(t) and ys(t), respectively. Figure 2.
Schematic of the planar motion of the articulated vehicle.

The main goal is to eliminate the position deviation between the point f at the present time (t) and the point S at the time of (t+td). The delay time, td, is the time required for the articulated vehicle to travel the distance between the rear end of the trailer (point S) and the fifth wheel (point f), which can be approximated as (34)td=LsVxt
The squared Euclidean distance between point S(t+td) and point f(t) may be defined as the tracking error at the time of t+td (35)e(t+td)=[xs(t+td)-xf(t)]2+[ys(t+td)-yf(t)]2

Now, an innovative approach is developed to define the reference articulation angle. Briefly, the position of point S for the time t+td is predicted by Taylor’s series expansion and kinematics relationships between the points S and f. Then, the reference articulation angle will be found on the basis of the elimination of the defined tracking error.

Referring to Figure 2, the longitudinal and lateral velocity of the fifth wheel can be expressed in the global coordinate as follows (36)Vxf(t)=Vxt(t)cosΨt(t)+rt(t)LwtsinΨt(t) -Vyt(t)sinΨt(t) (37)Vyf(t)=Vxt(t)sinΨt(t)-rt(t)LwtcosΨt(t) +Vyt(t)cosΨt(t) where Ψt(t) is the yaw angle of the tractor unit at the present time (t). The kinematics relationships between the trailer rear end and the fifth wheel can be written as follows (38)xs(t)=xf(t)-LscosΨs(t) (39)ys(t)=yf(t)-LssinΨs(t) where Ψs(t) is the yaw angle of the semi-trailer unit at the present time (t). From Taylor’s first order expansion, the predicted displacement of the fifth wheel in longitudinal and lateral directions at the time instant t+Δt may be approximated as follows (40)xf(t+Δt)=xf(t)+Vxf(t)Δt (41)yf(t+Δt)=yf(t)+Vyf(t)Δt where Δt is the time increment. From equations (38) to (41), the following expressions are obtained (42)xs(t+Δt)=xf(t)+Vxf(t)Δt-LscosΨs(t+Δt) (43)ys(t+Δt)=yf(t)+Vyf(t)Δt-LssinΨs(t+Δt)

By iterating equations (42) and (43), the position of point S at the next time step, t+2Δt, can be predicted as (44)xs(t+2Δt)=xf(t+Δt)+Vxf(t+Δt)Δt -LscosΨs(t+2Δt)xs(t+2Δt)=xf(t)+Vxf(t)Δt+Vxf(t+Δt)Δt -LscosΨs(t+2Δt) (45)ys(t+2Δt)=yf(t)+Vyf(t)Δt-LssinΨs(t+Δt)ys(t+2Δt)=yf(t)+Vyf(y)Δt+Vyf(t+Δt)Δt -LssinΨs(t+2Δt)

By continuing the iteration, the position at the final time, t+td, can be predicted as follows (46)xs(t+jΔt)=xs(t+td)=xf(t) +∑i=0j-1[Vxf(t+iΔt)Δt]-LscosΨs(t+td) (47)ys(t+jΔt)=ys(t+td)=yf(t) +∑i=0j-1[Vyf(t+iΔt)Δt]-LssinΨs(t+td)
where j is an integer value that can be calculated as (48)j=tdΔt=LsVxtΔt

Substituting equations (46) and (47) into the tracking error defined in equation (35), the following relation can be obtained (49)e(t+td)=[∑i=0j-1[Vxf(t+iΔt)Δt]-LscosΨs(t+td)]2 +[∑i=0j-1[Vyf(t+iΔt)Δt]-LssinΨs(t+td)]2

The above predicted error can be easily converted to the tracking error at the present time (t) by backward shift operation from i=0 to i=-j as follows (50)e(t)=[∑i=-j-1[Vxf(t+iΔt)Δt]-LscosΨs(t)]2 +[∑i=-j-1[Vyf(t+iΔt)Δt]-LssinΨs(t)]2

Now, using the above equation, if the following two conditions are satisfied, the tracking error is forced to converge to zero value (51)cosΨs(t)=∑i=-j-1[Vxf(t+iΔt)Δt]Ls (52)sinΨs(t)=∑i=-j-1[Vyf(t+iΔt)Δt]Ls
Moreover, by dividing equation (51) by equation (52), the desired yaw angle of the trailer can be expressed as (53)Ψsd(t)=arctan(∑i=-j-1[Vyf(t+iΔt)Δt]∑i=-j-1[Vxf(t+iΔt)Δt])
The relationship between the trailer yaw angle, tractor yaw angle and the articulation angle is defined as (54)γ=Ψs-Ψt
Finally, the resulting desired articulation angle is presented as (55)γd=-Ψt(t)+arctan(∑i=-j-1[Vyf(t+iΔt)Δt]∑i=-j-1[Vxf(t+iΔt)Δt])

So, the proposed desired articulation angle is obtained in two steps. Firstly, using the equations (36) and (37), the longitudinal and lateral velocities of the fifth wheel are determined in each sampling time. Secondly, from the most recent vector of data points (Vxf,Vyf) of length j, the desired articulation angle is obtained using the equation (55). It is clear from the procedure stated above that vehicle states including Vxt(t), Vyt(t), Ψt(t) and rt(t) need to be known. In the current research, it is assumed that the mentioned vehicle states are available. Although rt(t) can be measured using standard sensors, the other states may be estimated using observers which is not discussed here.

sec.title: Control system design
sec.p: The main goal of the control system is to make the actual articulation angle track the desired value proposed in the previous section. To achieve this goal, active steering control of the trailer’s wheels is proposed. It is important to note that active steering control depends on tyre lateral force, which is proportional to the steering angle only in a small lateral acceleration range owing to the saturation property of the tyre.27

It is expected that the trailer rear end follows the trajectory of the fifth wheel as the desired articulation angle is tracked. As stated in the section ‘The vehicle and tyre model’, the semi-trailer axles are steerable. In this article, the control steering angles of the trailer’s middle axle are determined based on the fuzzy logic theory. To design the control system, the relationship between the generated active steering angle and the articulation angle needs to be analyzed first. Referring to Figure 3, the comparison of the actual articulation angle with the reference response can be depicted in two distinct cases. The error between the actual articulation angle and the desired response is defined as (56)eγ=γ-γd Figure 3.
Two general situations in articulated vehicle cornering during the activation of the control system.
It is easy to find from Figure 3 that active steer angle, δms, has the same sign with the eγ. Thus there exists a straightforward relationship between eγ and δms.

Recently, the number of the applications of fuzzy logic to vehicle control has significantly increased with good results.28–30 Fuzzy logic controller (FLC) is proven to be more robust and their performances are less sensitive to parametric variations than conventional controllers.31 On the other hand, the directional characteristics of the vehicle are highly nonlinear and subjected to great uncertainty. In this article, the trailer steering controller is designed based on the fuzzy logic. The structure of the control system is depicted in Figure 4. Figure 4.
The structure of the control system.

As shown in Figure 4, The controller has two input signals, the articulation angle error, eγ, and the error rate of change, e·γ. The fuzzy logic controller output is the steering angle of the trailer’s middle axle.

The normalized data base is given in Figure 5. Triangular membership functions are used, except at the extreme ends, as shown in Figure 5. The rule base for the controller is given in Table 1. It should be noted that the rule base has been developed based on the expert knowledge and simulations of various maneuvers under different conditions. Figure 5.
Membership functions of eγ, e·γ and δms. Table 1.
Fuzzy rules for articulation angle controller.
eγ e·γ δms eγ e·γ δms eγ e·γ δms
N N NB NS Z NS PS PM P
N NM NB NS PS Z PS P P
N NS N NS PM PS PM N NS
N Z N NS P PM PM NM Z
N PS NM Z N N PM NS PS
N PM NS Z NM NM PM Z PM
N P Z Z NS NS PM PS P
NM N NB Z Z Z PM PM P
NM NM N Z PS PS PM P PB
NM NS N Z PM PM P N Z
NM Z NM Z P P P NM PS
NM PS NS PS N NM P NS PM
NM PM Z PS NM NS P Z P
NM P PS PS NS Z P PS P
NS N N PS Z PS P PM PB
NS NM N PS PS PM P P PB
NS NS NM

As stated above, the steer angle of the trailer’s middle axle sets to be equal to FLC output. To adjust the steer angles of the other two axles, a method proposed in Cheng et al.13 is used. A key point of this method is to equalize the lateral forces of the semi-trailer’s wheels. Consequently, all tyre slip angles should be equivalent. Therefore, the steering angles of the other two axles are (57)δfs=arctan(tan(δms)+LtsVxtrt) (58)δrs=arctan(tan(δms)-LtsVxtrt)

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
In order to evaluate the effect of the proposed method, a number of simulations using SIMULINK software are carried out on the nonlinear vehicle model presented in the ‘Vehicle and tyre model’ section. It is necessary to make a comparison to better understand the effect of the proposed desired articulation angle on the system performance. Hence, the proposed approach is compared against two methods employed in previous studies. Both methods are briefly discussed below:
Method 1: the Control structure of the method 1 is similar to the proposed system in the current research. However, the desired articulation, γd', has been defined based on the assumption that a constant steering angle is applied by driver21
(59) γd'=arctan2dpVxtgrδftVxt2-(dpgrδft)2

However, preliminary results indicated that the above desired articulation angle cannot provide a proper response. From equation (59), it is found that the length of the semi-trailer is not taken into consideration. Therefore, the desired articulation angle and driver steering angle have the same phase in terms of time. This could cause the control steering angle to be harsh and consequently it may deteriorate the performance of the system. To cope with this problem, the γd' is modified as follows (60)γdm'=kγ1+TγΔγd' where kγ is the gain factor, Tγ the time lag and Δ the Laplace operator. The coefficients are design parameters which depend on the dimensions and the vehicle speed.
Method 2: The control system in method 2 is constructed based on the Notsu’s idea.10 Briefly speaking, the course angle of the semi-trailer’s rear end is chosen as the control variable and the course angle of the fifth wheel is also selected as the desired response. The control system steers the semi-trailer wheels to make the course angle of the trailer rear end track the course angle of the fifth wheel.

In the remainder of this section, two different maneuvers are simulated. The first one is a low-speed 90° turn to investigate the effect of the proposed method on path following performance improvement at low speeds. The second one is a high-speed lane change maneuver which is conducted to evaluate the effect of the proposed method on high-speed path following performance. The vehicle parameters are listed in Table 2. It is noted that the parameters are chosen based on the values used in Sampson.32 Table 2.
Vehicle parameters.
Parameters Symbol Value
Longitudinal stiffness of one tyre Csi 160 kN/unit slip
Cornering stiffness of one tyre Cαi 143.3 kN/rad
Tractor inertia moment about the yaw axis Izt 20,679 kg m2
Semitrailer inertia moment about the yaw axis Izs 238,898 kg m2
Distance between the trailer center of gravity and coupling point Lfs 5.65 m
Distance between the tractor center of gravity and tractor front axle Lft 1.11 m
Distance between the tractor center of gravity and tractor rear axle Lrt 2.58 m
Distance between the trailer center of gravity and trailer middle axle Lrs 2.047 m
Distance between the fifth wheel and the rear end of the semitrailer LS 10 m
Distance between adjacent trailer axles Lts 1.31 m
Distance between the tractor center of gravity and coupling point Lwt 1.96 m
Total mass of the tractor unit mt 6525 kg
Total mass of the trailer unit ms 33,221 kg
Wheel radius R 0.5 m
Track width of the tractor unit Twt 2.04 m
Track width of the trailer unit Tws 2 m
Nominal friction coefficient between tyre and ground μ 0.9

sec.title: Low-speed 90° turn
sec.p:
The vehicle runs at initial speed of 15 km/h on a dry road with the steering input shown in Figure 6. In Figure 7, the vehicle lateral acceleration during the maneuver is depicted. The maximum lateral acceleration generated in this maneuver is 0.18 g. Figure 8 shows the animated vehicle motions with both proposed method and with no control. It is easy to find that the proposed method is very effective at reducing path tracking deviation of the trailer rear end compared to the passive vehicle. Figure 6.
Steering angle in low-speed 90° turn. Figure 7.
Lateral acceleration of the tractor unit in low-speed 90° turn. Figure 8.
Paths of vehicle: (a) with proposed method, (b) without control.

The desired articulation angle generated by the reference model presented in the section ‘Derivation of the desired articulation angle’, is shown by the solid line in Figure 9. The articulation angles in the cases without control and with the proposed method are also shown by dot and dash-dot lines, respectively. It can be seen that the proposed fuzzy logic controller provides satisfactory level of tracking performance to the desired values. Figure 9.
Articulation angle response.

In Figure 10(a) and (b), the vehicle motion with both control method 1, and control method 2, for the same maneuver are depicted, respectively. It can be seen that for this maneuver, the method 1, provides a good response. For the articulated vehicle with the dimensions given in Table 2, kγ=1 and Tγ=1 have been found to be good choices in this maneuver. It can also be seen that for the method 2, the steady-state path tracking error has occurred and the semi-trailer rear end does not closely follow the tractor path even when it goes out of the corner. As stated in Notsu et al.,10 this is due to the fact that method 2 has used the course angle as the control variable. Figure 10.
Paths of vehicle: (a) with method 1, (b) with method 2.

To provide a good comparison among the methods, the area of bounded region between fifth wheel path and trailer rear end path is computed during a maneuver. This value may be chosen as a performance measure. In Figure 11, the normalized value of this performance measure for the case without control and with three control methods has been depicted. It is clear from Figure 11, both proposed method and method 1 reduced the swept area by 80% compared with the conventional vehicle. Figure 11.
Normalized swept area of various methods.

sec.title: High-speed lane change maneuver
sec.p:
In this simulation scenario, high-speed lane change maneuver is performed. The vehicle initially travels with a velocity of 70 km/h on a dry road and the steering angle made one period of sine wave with the amplitude of 3° and frequency of 0.5 Hz. In Figure 12, the vehicle lateral acceleration is shown. The maximum lateral acceleration generated in this maneuver is 0.23 g. Figure 12.
Lateral acceleration of the tractor unit in lane change maneuver.

The articulation angles in the cases without control and with the proposed method are shown by in Figure 13. Figure 13.
articulation angle response.

The lane change paths of the four test vehicles are compared in Figure 14. Figure 14.
Lane change paths of vehicles: (a) without control, (b) with proposed method, (c) with method 1 and (d) with method 2.

It is clear that the proposed method demonstrated the best tracking performance. For method 1, the best selection of design parameters to achieve the fifth wheel tracking are kγ=4.6 and Tγ=1.5 which have been determined by numerous simulations. However, it is clear that the method 1 cannot provide satisfactory level of path tracking in lane change maneuver. From Figure 14(d), it can also be found that there is no remarkable difference between the proposed method and the method 2 in high-speed tracking performance. The steer angles of middle trailer axle for three mentioned control methods are shown in Figure 15. As expected, the shape of the steer angle curves in the proposed method and the method 2 are similar. In this maneuver, the maximum rate of change of the demanded steering angle by the proposed steering controller is 12 deg/s, which is practically attainable. Figure 15.
The control steering angle in three control methods.

In Figure 16, the defined performance measure in the section ‘Low-speed 90° turn’ has been depicted for the lane change maneuver. It is easy to find that the proposed method demonstrated the superior performance in terms of reducing off-tracking. Figure 16.
Normalized swept area of various methods.

list-item.p: A systematic method to define a reference articulation angle was developed in this article. A computer simulation study clarified that the tracking of the proposed desired value made the rear end of the semitrailer closely follow the fifth wheel path in both low-speed sharp turning and high-speed lane change maneuvers.
A fuzzy logic controller was designed to track the proposed desired articulation angle through steering the trailer wheels. It was shown that the controller can effectively track the desired values.

The effectiveness of the proposed method has been studied using comparative analysis of the three methods. Compared with the conventional methods (method 1 and method 2), the proposed method exhibits superior performance in terms of reducing off-tracking in different driving situations.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Calculation of the tyre normal loads
sec.p:
In order to compute the normal forces, the free body diagrams of the tractor and trailer units are depicted in Figure 17. Figure 17.
Free body diagram of the articulated vehicle.

The normal loads of tyres are computed as a function of the vehicle weight, longitudinal accelerations, lateral accelerations and coupling forces. Obviously, the normal loads of each tyre (Fzi), can be defined as the sum of the static load (Fzsi), dynamic load transfer in longitudinal direction (Fzxi) and dynamic load transfer in lateral direction (Fzyi) (61)Fzi=Fzsi+Fzxi+Fzyiwith i=1,2,…,10 The major forces acting on the tractor and semi-trailer are shown in Figure 17. The following terminologies are defined in order to simplify the representation of the computations of the normal forces (62)Fzfx=Fzs1+Fzx1+Fzs2+Fzx2 (63)Fzrx=Fzs3+Fzx3+Fzs4+Fzx4 (64)Fzsx=∑i=510(Fzsi+Fzxi) (65)Fzry=Fzy1+Fzy3 (66)Fzly=Fzy2+Fzy4 (67)Fsry=Fzy5+Fzy7+Fzy9 (68)Fsly=Fzy6+Fzy8+Fzy10

Firstly, using the side views of the tractor and trailer units in Figure 17, the sum of the static and longitudinal dynamic loads can be computed. Referring to Figure 17(b), by summing moments about the point A, Fzsx can be determined (69)Fzsx=msgLfs+msasxhs-Ffxhf(Lfs+Lrs)

It is assumed that the sum of the static load and longitudinal transfer load is equal for all wheels on the semi-trailer unit. So, the following relation is defined (70)Fzsi+Fzxi=msgLfs+msasxhs-Ffxhf6(Lfs+Lrs)with i=5,6,7,8,9,10
Taking moment about the contact patch between semi-trailer middle tyres and road surface, gives the normal load on the fifth wheel (71)Ffz=msgLfs+msasxhs-Ffxhf(Lfs+Lrs)

Similarly, Fzfx and Fzrx can be computed readily by taking a moment about the points B and C, respectively (72)Fzfx=mtgLrt-mtatxht-Ffxhf+Ffz(Lrt-Lwt)(Lft+Lrt) (73)Fzrx=mtgLft+mtatxht+Ffxhf+Ffz(Lft+Lwt)(Lft+Lrt)

The some of the static load and longitudinal transfer load for each wheel on the same axle of the tractor unit is also assumed to be equal. Hence (74)Fzsi+Fzxi=mtgLrt-mtatxht-Ffxhf+Ffz(Lrt-Lwt)2(Lft+Lrt)with i=1,2 and (75)Fzsi+Fzxi=mtgLft+mtatxht+Ffxhf+Ffz(Lft+Lwt)2(Lft+Lrt)with i=3,4

Now, the dynamic load transfer in lateral direction is determined. Referring to the front view of the tractor unit in Figure 17(c), by summing moments about the contact patch of the right tyres, Fzry can be determined (76)Fzry=-mtatyht-FfyhfTt
Similarly Fzly can be obtained by summing moments about the contact patch of the left tyres (77)Fzly=mtatyht+FfyhfTt

Therefore, the lateral load transfer for each wheel of the tractor unit can be obtained as follows (78)Fzy1=(-mtatyht-Ffyhf2Tt)LrtLft+Lrt (79)Fzy2=(mtatyht+Ffyhf2Tt)LrtLft+Lrt (80)Fzy3=(-mtatyht-Ffyhf2Tt)LftLft+Lrt (81)Fzy4=(mtatyht+Ffyhf2Tt)LftLft+Lrt
Similarly, referring to the front view of the semi-trailer, the lateral load transfer can be obtained (82)Fsry=-msasyhs+FfyhfTs (83)Fsly=msasyhs-FfyhfTs
Under the assumption of the equal distribution of the lateral load transfer on the right side tyres, the following relation can be obtained (84)Fzyi=-msasyhs+Ffyhf3Ts with i=5,7,9
Similarly, for the left side tyres of the semi-trailer unit the following relation is defined (85)Fzyi=msasyhs-Ffyhf3Ts with i=6,8,10

Therefore, the normal force for each tyre is obtained as follows (86)Fz1=mtgLrt-mtatxht-Ffxhf+Ffz(Lrt-Lwt)2(Lft+Lrt) +(-mtatyht-Ffyhf2Tt)LrtLft+Lrt (87)Fz2=mtgLrt-mtatxht-Ffxhf+Ffz(Lrt-Lwt)2(Lft+Lrt) +(mtatyht+Ffyhf2Tt)LrtLft+Lrt (88)Fz3=mtgLft+mtatxht+Ffxhf+Ffz(Lft+Lwt)2(Lft+Lrt) +(-mtatyht-Ffyhf2Tt)LftLft+Lrt (89)Fz4=mtgLft+mtatxht+Ffxhf+Ffz(Lft+Lwt)2(Lft+Lrt) +(mtatyht+Ffyhf2Tt)LftLft+Lrt (90)Fz5,z7,z9=msgLfs+msasxhs-Ffxhf6(Lfs+Lrs) +-msasyhs+Ffyhf3Ts (91)Fz6,z8,z10=msgLfs+msasxhs-Ffxhf6(Lfs+Lrs) +msasyhs-Ffyhf3Ts
